Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Language documentation of Tai Khamti in Myanmar

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Southeast Asia has long been an area of US strategic interest, as well as an area of immense linguistic diversity. This project investigates Tai languages spoken in Khamti District, Myanmar (Burma), a place that has seen almost no linguistic fieldwork. It unites traditional language documentation with modern quantitative analysis, using new field data to improve our understanding of these languages. This hybrid approach enables innovative answers to research questions that traditional methods have not sufficiently answered, and that modern methods cannot answer with only the data currently available.

Fieldwork will focus on modern evidence for historical tones and phonology in the Tai languages, while also providing important linguistic and cultural context for the data. The project also undertakes an ambitious survey of all existing lexical data, from resources published in more than a dozen countries. These results will be organized alongside the new field data into a database designed for quantitative study of Tai language history, which will be used to produce a dissertation, a corpus of texts, and a comparative dictionary.

As some of the first linguistic fieldwork in Myanmar, this project improves our understanding of the language situation in a long inaccessible part of the world, which serves to strengthen US relations with Myanmar. Improvement in these areas contributes to greater regional stability within Southeast Asia, further advancing American political and economic interests in this part of the world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has supported fieldwork for a dissertation uniting traditional language documentation with modern quantitative analysis in order to further our understanding of Tai Khamti [ISO 639-3: kht], a language in the Kra-Dai language family. The dissertation advances our specific knowledge of the language family and its history, but it also has implications for a general theory of sound change in lexical tone systems.

In tonal languages, speakers vary the level and contour of the pitch of their voice in order to form words with different meanings. Just as with any other aspect of phonology, tone systems in closely related languages gradually change over time to become less and less similar. Tai Khamti spoken in Khamti District of northwest Myanmar is a previously unstudied dialect that has been separated for more than two centuries from its closest linguistic relatives, leading to a different tone system. Comparing Tai Khamti data from this dialect with related dialects spoken in Northeast India and other areas of Myanmar, as well as comparison with other languages throughout the language family, thus makes for an important test case for new methods in historical linguistics.

The hybrid approach to methodology made possible by this grant lets us seek answers to questions that traditional methods have not sufficiently answered. The fieldwork combined both targeted study of the tones used by a speakers of varying ages in multiple villages in the area, as well as general documentation of the lexicon, grammar, and texts of this endangered dialect of Tai Khamti. This grant also supported an exhaustive survey of all existing Tai fieldwork and dialectology reports, from resources published in more than a dozen countries.

In addition to the dissertation, major products of this grant include a set of high quality audio recordings to be digitally archived, a comparative lexicon of Tai Khamti as spoken at different villages, a corpus of Tai Khamti stories and songs that have been transcribed and linguistically annotated, an aggregated dataset of historical tones from nearly 400 Tai languages and dialects, and nine research presentations given by the co-PI at conferences and workshops.

As some of the first modern linguistic fieldwork conducted in Myanmar, this grant has broader impact by improving our understanding of the language situation in a long inaccessible and politically volatile part of the world, which can only serve to strengthen US relations with Myanmar. Improvement to international understanding and relations contributes to greater regional stability within Southeast Asia, further advancing American political and economic interests in this part of the world while simultaneously advancing scientific knowledge.
